title: Stop copying Western culture, tap into Ghana’s rich rhythms - Prof John Collins
text:
Source: Ghana | Myjoyonline.com | Ernest Dela Aglanu (Twitter: @delaXdela / Instagram: citizendela) Date: 23-10-2015 Time: 08:10:11:am Prof John Collins 
Ghanaian musicians have been challenged to stop copying Western culture and rather explore local rhythms and culture to produce their music. 
Prof John Collins, a music professor at the University of Ghana, who threw the challenge, said the country in particular, and Africa in general, is blessed with so a rich culture and rhythms that musicians can tap into. 
He observed that because of the huge potential, foreigners are trooping here to pinch into our rhythms to sell because they have run out of rhythms. 
“I would say that Ghana and in particular Africa in general has one of the richest musical cultures on this planet,” the music professor said during an interview on Personality Profile on Joy FM with Lexis Bill Thursday. 
He estimated that 2,000 languages are spoken in Africa with 30 key languages spoken in Ghana alone and “every language has different rhythms.” A country like Britain, he added, has only one culture. 
“But here you have 30 cultures and each culture is producing its own music so that is repository of new things that the young Ghanaian can draw from; traditional rhythms, traditional music and they can polish up or modify and do whatever they want,” Prof Collins noted. 
He advised musicians in Ghana “not to copy somebody else’s music, somebody else’s vision, somebody else’s dream, it has to come from here and the fact is you have such a rich culture.” 
The music professor expressed worry that, “right now loads of white people are coming here to pinch your rhythms and put them onto records because they have run out of rhythms over there that’s why they’ve gone into world music.” 
“Younger Ghanaians I would say that you have to turn towards Ghanaian music…be original,” he admonished.
